Client side text editor in Etherpad and its Etherpad Lite fork is implemented using [[Appjet]]'s in-browser text editor written in Javascript.
 
Client side text editor in Etherpad and its Etherpad Lite fork is implemented using [[Appjet]]'s in-browser text editor written in Javascript.
    −
== Launch ==
+
.<ref>{{cite web
−
Etherpad was launched on November 19, 2008 by David Greenspan, [[Aaron Iba]], and J.D. Zamfirescu (the latter two being former [[Google]] employees).<ref name="blogoscoped">{{cite web
  −
| url = http://blogoscoped.com/archive/2008-11-20-n42.html
  −
| title = EtherPad
  −
| author = Philip Lenssen
  −
| publisher = [[Google Blogoscoped]]
  −
| date = November 20, 2008
  −
}}</ref>
  −
They were later joined by former Googler Daniel Clemens and designer David Cole.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://etherpad.com/ep/about/company |title=AppJet Company Overview |publisher=EtherPad |date= |accessdate=February 14, 2013}}</ref> The original website was <code>etherpad.com</code>.
  −   −
Etherpad was covered by [[Slashdot]] on November 21, 2008,<ref>{{cite web
  −
| url = http://tech.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=08/11/21/1626208
  −
| title = A Web App For Real-Time Collaborative Writing
  −
| date = November 21, 2008
  −
| publisher = [[Slashdot]]
  −
}}</ref> resulting in [[Slashdot effect|server slowdown and downtime]]. This led the developers to temporarily revert the tool to [[Beta version|closed beta]], not allowing new pads to be created (but providing full and unrestricted access to the existing ones), while the server infrastructure was being improved.<ref>{{cite web
   
| url = http://etherpad.com/ep/blog/posts/etherpad-temporarily-reverts-to-closed-beta
 
| url = http://etherpad.com/ep/blog/posts/etherpad-temporarily-reverts-to-closed-beta
 
| title = EtherPad Temporarily Reverts to Closed Beta
